html: Forming an intrinsic part of Babylon’s socio-economic structure, Tyre—like its sister city Sidon (vv 2, 12)—typifies Babylon’s shipping and mercantile establishment. Tyre’s merchants anciently founded trading colonies throughout the entire known world. Isaiah’s concept of a Greater Babylon—a composite entity that includes a worldwide shipping empire—informs John’s Babylon the Great and its fall, including the demise of Babylon’s seafaring enterprise (Revelation 18:11-24). The sirens of Tyre’s ships, which sounded joyfully at their departure, now wail at the prospect of having no ports of call.
